head.title: Freeways Are the 'Field of Dreams' for Special Interests

hedline.hl1: Freeways Are the 'Field of Dreams' for Special Interests

abstract.p: Transportation engineer Leon Goodman letter contends that bus and high-occupancy-vehicle lanes began with bus lane on Lincoln Tunnel's New Jersey approach; says major HOV initiatives since then have not advanced because they have not been given sufficient development time to accomplish their objectives

block.p: Re ''Thinking Ahead on Traffic'' (editorial, Nov. 4): Bus and high-occupancy-vehicle, or H.O.V., lanes began here with the bus lane on the Lincoln Tunnel's New Jersey approach, followed by similar lanes on the approaches to the Midtown Tunnel and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. But major H.O.V. initiatives since then have not advanced.

Re ''Thinking Ahead on Traffic'' (editorial, Nov. 4): Bus and high-occupancy-vehicle, or H.O.V., lanes began here with the bus lane on the Lincoln Tunnel's New Jersey approach, followed by similar lanes on the approaches to the Midtown Tunnel and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. But major H.O.V. initiatives since then have not advanced.

In the late 1970's, opposition stymied the proposed Queens Transitway to Kennedy International Airport, along with a proposed H.O.V. scheme for the Long Island Expressway in central Queens. By comparison, there is an airport busway now under construction leading to the Pittsburgh Airport. H.O.V. lanes need to be given sufficient development time to accomplish their objectives.
The writer is a transportation engineer and planner.
